Betrand Russell's orbiting teapot analogy concerns the provenance of belief. He wanted to make a point which is rather less than obvious to most religious believers, namely that those who make extraordinary claims that are impossible to verify bear the burden of proof before they need be taken too seriously. 
 
 He chose to illustrate this by means of a simple analogy that is immediately capable of being grasped, and isn't loaded with centuries of connotations and other traditional baggage, namely an imaginary teapot too small to be telescopically observed that is allegedly in orbit between earth and Mars. Anyone who insists on the necessary existence of this teapot is therefore reasonably required to provide some evidence that it is there.
 
 Similarly with arguments about the existence of any specific deity. Someone who claims a particular deity exists can be reasonably asked to provide evidence for it, because otherwise, why should anyone believe in it? They wouldn't believe in an ordinary, orbiting teapot on the same lack of evidence, so why believe in something even more extraordinary and complex as a specific deity?
 
 The analogy is appropriate because it compares the rationale for belief, and acceptance of that belief by others. It doesn't matter that Russell picked a prosaic teapot to illustrate the provenance of belief. What matters is the grounds on which claims are made and defended, and that is what the analogy is intended to illustrate. Despite the fact that like all analogies it is limited in scope, and not everyone will understand it or learn from it, it serves its didactic purpose well.

 A form of logical inference or an instance of it, based on the assumption that if two things are known to be alike in some respects, then they must be alike in other respects.
 
 
 False analogy:
 A false analogy is an unjustified inference drawn on the basis of similarities between two items or types of items. The teapot analogy is pertinent:
 
 I think what Jim is doing here is attacking Russell's analogy for being what it is not: a comparison of the essence of a teapot to the essence of a deity. That seems to me to be a deliberate misconstruing of the analogy, a straw man that Russell manifestly did not have in mind, and it's constructed with the intention of dismissing the analogy without having to consider its implications.
 
 Russell was comparing the relevant similarities between methods of justifying a belief in an unlikely physical object that cannot be observed, with justifying a belief in a real deity that cannot be seen. Jim goes out of his way to believe that Russell intended the comparison to be about essences, instead, despite the clear wording of Russell's argument.
 
 For the life of me, I cannot see how a reading of Russell's essay could result in such a misconstruction by accident. It's a red herring.
 
 Let's look at the relevant paragraphs concerning the teapot in Russell's essay, Is There a God?, this time quoted in full so the context is evident:
 
 
Many orthodox people speak as though it were the business of sceptics to disprove received dogmas rather than of dogmatists to prove them. This is, of course, a mistake. If I were to suggest that between the Earth and Mars there is a china teapot revolving about the sun in an elliptical orbit, nobody would be able to disprove my assertion provided I were careful to add that the teapot is too small to be revealed even by our most powerful telescopes. But if I were to go on to say that, since my assertion cannot be disproved, it is intolerable presumption on the part of human reason to doubt it, I should rightly be thought to be talking nonsense. If, however, the existence of such a teapot were affirmed in ancient books, taught as the sacred truth every Sunday, and instilled into the minds of children at school, hesitation to believe in its existence would become a mark of eccentricity and entitle the doubter to the attentions of the psychiatrist in an enlightened age or of the Inquisitor in an earlier time. It is customary to suppose that, if a belief is widespread, there must be something reasonable about it. I do not think this view can be held by anyone who has studied history. Practically all the beliefs of savages are absurd. In early civilizations there may be as much as one percent for which there is something to be said. In our own day.... But at this point I must be careful. We all know that there are absurd beliefs in Soviet Russia. If we are Protestants, we know that there are absurd beliefs among Catholics. If we are Catholics, we know that there are absurd beliefs among Protestants. If we are Conservatives, we are amazed by the superstitions to be found in the Labour Party. If we are Socialists, we are aghast at the credulity of Conservatives. I do not know, dear reader, what your beliefs may be, but whatever they may be, you must concede that nine-tenths of the beliefs of nine-tenths of mankind are totally irrational. The beliefs in question are, of course, those which you do not hold. I cannot, therefore, think it presumptuous to doubt something which has long been held to be true, especially when this opinion has only prevailed in certain geographical regions, as is the case with all theological opinions.
 
 My conclusion is that there is no reason to believe any of the dogmas of traditional theology and, further, that there is no reason to wish that they were true. Man, in so far as he is not subject to natural forces, is free to work out his own destiny. The responsibility is his, and so is the opportunity. 

 
 In no part of this is it possible to conclude legitimately that Russell is comparing essences: he's examining the source and justification of belief. The first sentence sets out the problem he wants to address here: 
"Many orthodox people speak as though it were the business of sceptics to disprove received dogmas rather than of dogmatists to prove them."
 Here, Russell is pointing out a fact of belief that he wishes to show is unreasonable. He wants to show that the burden of proof for an extraordinary claim lies with the claimant, rather than the burden of disproof lying with the skeptic. He wants to show this, because many people believe the reverse, that it is logical to believe in a deity (or some other unverifiable object or entity) if someone else cannot disprove its existence. Consequently, he wracks his brains for a simple analogy, one that can be understood by skeptics and believers alike, to a claim that is in some sense plausible yet highly unlikely, and extraordinarily difficult, maybe impossible, to confirm.
 
 The reason he resorts to such a mundane analogy is made clear in this sentence: 
"If, however, the existence of such a teapot were affirmed in ancient books, taught as the sacred truth every Sunday, and instilled into the minds of children at school, hesitation to believe in its existence would become a mark of eccentricity and entitle the doubter to the attentions of the psychiatrist in an enlightened age or of the Inquisitor in an earlier time. It is customary to suppose that, if a belief is widespread, there must be something reasonable about it."
 It is not the essence of the teapot he is concerned with; it's the provenance of a hypothetical, traditional belief in it that is precisely analogous to the provenance of a belief in a deity. Russell argues against the fact that traditional belief is frequently accepted as truth, simply because it is traditional.
 
 It is in the subsequent part of his argument that he explains why he thinks it is invalid to use tradition, custom and habit as provenance for belief in unverifiable claims, by offering a number of examples, including some that modern believers in Christianity would themselves find absurd because they are not part of their own tradition. For example: 
"Practically all the beliefs of savages are absurd. In early civilizations there may be as much as one percent for which there is something to be said. In our own day.... But at this point I must be careful. We all know that there are absurd beliefs in Soviet Russia. If we are Protestants, we know that there are absurd beliefs among Catholics. If we are Catholics, we know that there are absurd beliefs among Protestants."
 Clearly, with this and further examples -- "The ['absurd'] beliefs in question are, of course, those which you do not hold." -- he is pointing out that any intrinsic absurdity of belief (as opposed to the validity of the provenance of said belief) is in the eye of the beholder, and that the only way of settling such a question is by providing evidence to justify such a belief. It is not a claim that any particular belief is objectively absurd; it's an argument that unverifiable beliefs cannot be legitimately defended as if they were beyond all doubt.
 
 The analogy holds, and I believe Jim has misconstrued its purpose, for his own rhetorical purposes. Russell was not making a trivial and inappropriate comparison: he was making an argument that extraordinary beliefs need commensurate justification. Now, religious believers may not like his point of view, but it is not a valid argument to simply dismiss the analogy as irrelevant by pretending it means something it didn't.

 "Actually I know the guy who made the world and he does care and I have the number for his answering machine."
 "Thank you, I feel much better now and I will tell my friends so that they can feel better too."
 
 with:
 
 "I feel very small and the world is very big and uncaring."
 "Did you know there's a small teapot in orbit around the sun?"
 "No I did not, and attaining this minor enlightenment has not significantly alleviated my existential disquiet."
 
 It isn't reasonable to believe that a god would make the whole of the universe just to give a few apes something to look at at night. It isn't reasonable to believe creation revolves around us. But it is terribly, terribly appealing, hence the disproportionate proliferation of creation myths in which our good selves feature prominently compared to the far greater potential variety of equally reasonable creation hypotheses in which we are irrelevant extras. If there is anything wrong with Russell's analogy, it is his failure to mention that the teapot grants three wishes to those who believe in it.

 I don't think Russell is arguing with this analogy that because it would be absurd to believe in an orbiting teapot, therefore it would be equally absurd to believe in a god. Or if he was, he'd be wrong, but I don't think he was. He doesn't strike me as simpleminded enough to think, "no teapot, therefore no god". 
 
 The analogy was intended to illustrate a specific point, namely that one should be rightly skeptical of unusual and unsubstantiated claims. It's a point about logic and evidence. It's not a disproof of god, nor will it impress anyone such as Jim who feels an emotional need to believe in one, or an Aristotelean who needs an uncaused cause.
 
 So if one argues that the analogy is supposed to provide a strong reason to disbelieve in god, then you could say it failed, but it doesn't seem to me to be intended to be all that sweeping. In any case, Russell did not limit his argument against belief to this one analogy. If people want to fault Russell for not providing the killer analogy that vanquished religious belief at a stroke, I think they've got the wrong target. His claims there were much more modest, namely that one is not logically compelled to believe in God X without considerable proof.

 It's not difficult to show that the analogy doesn't disprove god, or that it isn't perfect in every respect. However, analogies aren't meant to be perfect representations of what they are intended to illuminate. They necessarily have limitations -- if they didn't, they would be the thing itself, and not an analogy to it. The differences are as informative as the similarities. As a didactic tool, the analogy works well. It can't answer all questions about the origins, persistence and validity of religious beliefs, but then as an analogy, it shouldn't be expected to.
 
 One shouldn't criticise an analogy for its imperfections. It needs to be appreciated for what it accomplishes in the way of illumination. As such, it neatly illustrates its point about the burden of proof, and the importance of verifiable evidence to belief, which are not trivial issues, and are not always appreciated by true believers. Specific arguments against belief in god for other reasons would, of course, be beyond this analogy. Let's not complain it doesn't do what it was never intended to do.
